awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of High performance Liquid Chromatography and Mass Spectrometry Instrumentation to Support Research and Training at the University of Puget Sound
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, the University of Puget Sound will acquire a liquid chromatography mass spectrometer system (LC/MS).   The system will be used to analyze the composition of samples obtained from various sources including those obtained from environmental and biological origins.  Liquid chromatography (LC) separates a mixture into its individual components.  Mass spectrometry (MS) then ionizes the components and determines their mass by measuring the mass to charge ratio (m/z) of the ions.  This is a widely used analytical tool to identify what is the composition of a mixture or material.  The instrument will be used by students in their research, training them with sophisticated, modern instrumentation.  Students in laboratory courses will be trained in its use.  In addition to its impact on the scientific curriculum at Puget Sound, the instrument will play a central role in a planned collaboration between Puget Sound and the Tacoma Science and Math Institute (SAMI), a magnet STEM high school.

This award has a environmental and biochemical research focus.  The proposal is aimed at enhancing research especially in areas such as (a) probing changes in lipid expression in biofilms exposed to antimicrobial peptides; (b) quantifying illicit drugs and pharmaceutical metabolites in wastewater; (c) carrying out comparative transcriptomic and proteomic analysis of phytochrome responses in plants; (d) examining the role of bisphenol A in the modulation of the reproductive neuroendocrine system; and (e) assessing the correlation between trophic level and bioaccumulation of persistent organic pollutants at abandoned sawmill sites in the Puget Sound.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the purchase of a ultra high performance liquid chromatography-quadropole time of flight (QTOF) mass spectrometry (MS) instrument (LC-MS) at the University of Puget Sound, a primarily undergraduate institution in Tacoma, Washington. The purchased instrument was a Waters Acquity UPLC with a Xevo G2XS QTOF. The new instrument allowed for high-resolution liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry measurements that were not possible with the ion trap instrument that the Chemistry department already had. The design of the instrument allows it to be used in a broad array of experiments, including both quantitative and qualitative measurements. It enabled new research to be performed on campus by several researchers and it greatly enhanced the quality of the undergraduate curriculum.

The instrument has been used by researchers in both the chemistry and biology departments and in a collaborative outreach project with the Tacoma Math and Science Institute (SAMI), a local public high school. PI Megan Gessel worked with 4 students to probe the structure and dynamics of antimicrobial peptides in liposomes, to better understand the influence of the chemical properties of a lipid bilayer on peptide:membrane interactions using hydrogen deuterium exchange mass spectrometry. Dr. Gessel recently purchased an additional instrument component that will allow for complimentary measurements of these systems by native protein mass spectrometry. This research would not be possible without the high mass resolution capabilities of the QTOF mass analyzer.

Co-PI Dan Burgard worked with 5 undergraduate students to quantitate small molecules in water. Three students worked in an NIH-funded wastewater-based epidemiology study to estimate cannabis use in Washington State. During the award period new LCMS protocols were developed to quantitate THC and THC-metabolites on the instrument and prepared samples were recently analyzed. Dr. Burgard has also begun to develop methods for a similar study to examine opioid use.

Major user Dr. Andreas Madlung worked with three students and one postdoc in proteomic experiments to study phytochrome signaling. Specifcally, they are using proteomics to compliment ongoing genomic work to understand which genes are involved in specific signaling resonses. Major user Dr. Siddarth Ramakrishnan, in collaboration with Dr. Gessel, worked with four students to measure levels of estradiol and bpa in zebrafish. Ramakrishnan studies the effects of endocrine disruptors on the gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) signaling system. The students successfully developed methods to extract estradiol and bisphenol A (bpa) and quantitate the compounds by LC-MS. Now, these methods are being used to correlate behavioral changes in zebrafish exposed to bpa with bpa levels in the fish tissue. These studies are currently being expanded to measure other endocrine disruptors, including bisphenol S (BPS). Finally, the instrument has also been used in the research of Dr. Bryan Thines, to study the levels of plant signaling compounds released in response to thermal stress. Currently, Thines is working with Gessel to probe changes in metabolite levels in Arabidopsis, in response to environmental stress.

In addition to research at the University of Puget Sound, Co-PI Burgard worked with Matt Lonsdale, a teacher at SAMI to develop a course-based research project for his students. The students worked to measured the efficacy of a storm-water biofilteration system at a local Tacoma park. Mr. Lonsdale developed an extraction and MS-analysis method during the summer. He taught his students the extraction and sample preparation and the students came to the University of Puget Sound campus to see the instrument. For the past two years, high school students have been collecting and extracting samples, which were subsequently analyzed by Mr. Lonsdale using the LC-MS. The students presented their results in a poster session and Mr Lonsdale also presented this research at a national conference. 

All of the research described above, as well as the outreach collaboration is ongoing. Overall, the project resulted in the publication of a peer-reviewed article, six undergraduate theses and numerous conference presentations. Many undergraduates gained valuable training and experience with start-of-the-art LC-MS. A total of 16 undergraduates used the instrument for long-term independent research projects, with additional students using the instrument for upper-level chemistry classes and roughly 60 high school students learning about the mass spectrometry analysis. 

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2018
Modified by: Megan Gessel
